post_text:
Beginning Monday, August 24, 2020, all game tickets must be purchased online.

Tickets will be available beginning at 10 AM every Monday for all home games played in Smithville. You can access the link below to Create an Account in preparation for future purchasing.

Tickets will be available until SOLD OUT. Please note we are only allowed 50% seating capacity at all venues, indoors or outdoors.

Each host school will sell tickets - SISD will NOT sell tickets for away games.

To purchase tickets for games (7th - 12th) hosted in Smithville ISD please go to the link below for tickets.

Information on how to Create an Account is posted on our SISD Athletics webpage at https://bit.ly/3j0sQgE or www.smithvilleisd.org - select Departments - select Athletics - select Event Tickets.

No student, staff, or parent passes will be accepted.

Thank you for your patience and understanding.

#SmithvilleISD #TigerPride

post_text:
Please consider taking the survey in the link below to help Connected Nation Texas and Bastrop County Cares assess the state of broadband in Bastrop County.

The survey will take 10 minutes and you can take it as a resident, business owner or designated respresentative of an organization, please go to:
https://www.myconnectedcommunity.org/bastrop-county/

They need our help to address internet connectivity in our county.

For more information about this broadband initiative or the Bastrop County Broadband Committee, please email info@bastropcares.org.

This was made possible by the St. David's Foundation.

PLEASE SHARE

#SmithvilleISD #BastropCountyCares #InternetConnectivity

August 3 at 10:27 AM ¬∑

Please see the below images for COVID-19 testing and hotline information for Bastrop County. Residents who qualify for testing at a Bastrop County Community Testing Site will now be able to choose to make an appointment at the Bastrop area location or the newly opened Elgin area location.

To learn more about the response to COVID-19 in Bastrop County, visit: https://www.co.bastrop.tx.us/page/em.coronavirus

Correction: The Elgin location is open until 4:30 PM, Monday through Friday

Smithville ISD is working to expand technology across the district to support our students and staff. Programs, like the Chromebook initiative and on-campus public WiFi are already underway. As the virtual learning plans move forward, the district is working to ensure that each student and staff member will have the tools and internet access they need to participate successfully in online and virtual learning.

Details on these SISD technology programs, internet access, and technology training information for parents will be available soon.

#SmithvilleISD #TigerPride

post_text:
July 17, 2020

Dear Smithville ISD Community,

Smithville administrative staff are continuing to work on the back to school plan. Things are changing on a daily basis. The plan is being developed based on guidance given by the Governor of Texas, Texas Education Agency, Commissioner of Education, and Bastrop County local health authorities. The Commissioner of Education plans to provide updated information to superintendents today. At this time the district is not ready to release a plan as we evaluate guidance provided by state and local health authorities. We are currently reviewing our start of school date and revisions to the academic calendar. The plan will include district and state guidelines for the virtual learning environment. Thank you for your patience as we work to provide you with an accurate plan for the start of school.

Sincerely,
Cheryl Burns
Superintendent

Superintendent Letter is also available on the district website at www.smithvilleisd.org

post_text:
Smithville I.S.D is seeking registrations for credit by examination for acceleration. Parents and students should request an exam from the Assistant Superintendent by July 13, 2020.

A student will be permitted to take an examination to earn credit for an academic course for which the student has no prior instruction.

The scheduled dates for the upcoming examinations are August 4-6, 2020. The passing score required to earn credit on an examination for acceleration is 80.

If you plan to take an examination for acceleration, you (or your parent) must register with the Assistant Superintendent no later than July 13, 2020. For further information, see Board policy EHDC local or call Michael Caudill at 512-237-2487.

#SmithvilleISD #CreditbyExam

post_text:
We are saddened to learn of the passing of Coach Buddy Kellar. Coach Kellar graduated from Smithville High School in 1953. After graduation, he served in the U.S. Army and later worked for Smithville ISD. Coach Kellar spent 38 years as a high school football coach.

This past season Coach Kellar joined the Smithville Tiger Football team on the field for pre-game festivities as an Honorary Captain to 'flip the coin'. It was a special treat to have him join the team on the field at Tiger Stadium.

Thank you for your service to our country and your time as an educator in your hometown of Smithville, Texas.

Our condolences go out to Coach Kellar's family and friends.

ALLFAITHSOFTHEPINES.COM

Taco Cabana is offering kids a free lunch ‚Äì including a bean and cheese taco, chips and queso and a drink ‚Äì at all Texas locations through the end of summer. The program is available to kids 12 and under, every weekday from 11 a.m. to noon.

The offer is available through the drive-thru only at all company-owned locations in Texas for a limited time. Children must be present and accompanied by a parent or guardian to receive a free meal. No purchase is necessary. For more info, visit www.tacocabana.com.

<<< Smithville ISD Child Nutrition will continue to serve Breakfast and Lunch on Monday's & Wednesday through the month of July! >>>

Thank you Taco Cabana for supporting the kids of Texas!

#SmithvilleISD #SISDCares

post_text:
Pandemic Electronic Benefit Transfer (P-EBT) is a one-time food benefit for families who lost access to free or reduced-price meals due to school closures. Eligible P-EBT families will receive application instructions from schools in late May. The P-EBT application is now open.

P-EBT food benefits are for children who received SNAP food benefits for March 2020 and children who are certified for free or reduced-price school meals during the 2019-20 Texas school year. For more information, visit: hhs.texas.gov/PEBT

Smithville ISD is gathering information to effectively plan for the 20-21 school year. While the Commissioner of Education has not provided final guidance on how next year will look, he has stated that we could be looking at multiple instructional options depending on the status of the COVID-19 virus. We are asking that you please fill out the information in the survey link below to help us plan after final guidance is provided from the Commissioner.

Please complete the survey by Monday June 8th, 2020. This survey should take about 5 minutes to complete.

Survey Link: https://bit.ly/2AznUOH

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "Please Please the Bees".

(Written and illustrated by Gerald Kelley, and read by Rashida Jones)

Life is sweet for Benedict. Every morning he wakes up to find jars of fresh honey on his back porch. He makes honey toast for breakfast, bakes honey cake in the afternoon, and drinks honey tea before bed. But one day, the jars on Benedict‚Äôs porch are empty. The bees in his backyard have gone on strike! They are tired of doing all the work around the hive. What can Benedict do to make the bees happy and bring sweetness back to his days?

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.
#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/-XFQNGJmLEk

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "As Fast As Words Could Fly".

(Written by Pamela M. Tuck, illustrated by Eric Velasquez, and read by Dul√© Hill)

Young Mason Steele takes pride in turning his father‚Äôs excited ramblings about the latest civil rights incidents into handwritten business letters. One day Pa comes home with a gift from his civil rights group: a typewriter. Thrilled with the present, Mason spends all his spare time teaching himself to type. Soon he knows where every letter on the keyboard is located. When the civil rights group wins a school desegregation case, Mason learns that now he will be attending a formerly all-white high school. Despite his fears and injustice from the students and faculty, Mason perseveres. He does well in school‚Äîespecially in his typing class. And when he competes in the county typing tournament, Mason decides to take a stand, using his skills to triumph over prejudice and break racial barriers.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.
#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/1_Zk4P50WT4

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "Snappsy The Alligator (Did Not Ask to Be in This Book)".

(Written by Julie Falatko, illustrated by Tim Miller, and read by David Harbour)

Snappsy the alligator is having a normal day when a pesky narrator steps in to spice up the story. Is Snappsy reading a book ... or is he making CRAFTY plans? Is Snappsy on his way to the grocery store ... or is he PROWLING the forest for defenseless birds and fuzzy bunnies? Is Snappsy innocently shopping for a party ...or is he OBSESSED with snack foods that start with the letter P? What‚Äôs the truth?

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.
#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/yU8OJWAZmZo

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "Sylvester and the Magic Pebble".

(Written and illustrated by William Steig and read by Reid Scott)

On a rainy day, Sylvester finds a magic pebble that can make wishes come true. But when a lion frightens him on his way home, Sylvester makes a wish that brings unexpected results. How Sylvester is eventually reunited with his loving family and restored to his true self makes a story that is beautifully tender and filled with magic.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.
#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/BNGUnk8JeLE

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "The Coal Thief".

(Written by Alane Adams, illustrated by Lauren Gallegos, and read by Christian Slater)

Brrr! Georgie wakes up to a freezing morning in 1920‚Äôs Pennsylvania and gets the bad news that there is no coal to heat the farmhouse‚Äîand he knows there is no money to buy more, either. Just after he finds this out, along comes his friend Harley, who drags him off on an adventure to find some mysterious ‚Äúblack gold.‚Äù Before Georgie can catch his breath, he‚Äôs in a pile of trouble‚Äîall the way up to his ears! Take a trip back in time and join Georgie in this heartwarming tale of mischief made and lessons learned in America‚Äôs storied past.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.
#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/ANZ0P4Edfd8

Brrr! Georgie wakes up to a freezing morning in 1920‚Äôs Pennsylvania and gets the bad news that there is no coal to heat the farmhouse‚Äîand he knows there is no money to buy more, either. Just after he finds this out, along comes his friend Harley, who drags him off on an adventure to find some mysterious ‚Äúblack gold.‚Äù Before Georgie can catch his breath, he‚Äôs in a pile of trouble‚Äîall the way up to his ears! Take a trip back in time and join Georgie in this heartwarming tale of mischief made and lessons learned in America‚Äôs storied past.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.
#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/ANZ0P4Edfd8

YOUTUBE.COM
The Coal Thief read by Christian Slater

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "How I Learned Geography".

(Written and illustrated by Uri Shulevitz and read by Ed O'Neill)

Having fled from war in their troubled homeland, a boy and his family are living in poverty in a strange country. Food is scarce, so when the boy‚Äôs father brings home a map instead of bread for supper, at first the boy is furious. But when the map is hung on the wall, it floods their cheerless room with color. As the boy studies its every detail, he is transported to exotic places without ever leaving the room, and he eventually comes to realize that the map feeds him in a way that bread never could.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.
#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "When A Dragon Moves In".

(Written by Jodi Moore, iIllustrated by Howard McWilliam, and read by Mark Duplass)

If you build a perfect sandcastle, a dragon will move in. And that‚Äôs exactly what happens to one very lucky boy at the beach. Dad is busy sunbathing and Mom is busy with her book, so the boy and dragon roam the beach together, flying a kite, braving the waves, and roasting marshmallows. But no one believes him when he shares the news of his magnificent dragon: Mom only hears the roar of the ocean, Dad thinks the dragon feather is a seagull feather, and know-it-all sis claims there‚Äôs no such thing as a dragon. That‚Äôs when the sandwiches mysteriously disappear, claw prints are found in the brownies, and dragon-giggles erupt from the strangest of places. Heh-heh-heh. Is there truly a mischievous dragon running around on the beach or is someone‚Äôs imagination running wild? Decide for yourself When a Dragon Moves In.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/6s7aSNUCkiM

YOUTUBE.COM

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "A Tale of Two Beasts".

(Written by Fiona Roberton, illustrated by Fiona Roberton, and read by Sarah Silverman)

There are two sides to every story. In Part One, a little girl finds a strange beast in the woods and takes it home as a pet. She feeds it, shows it off to her friends and gives it a hat. But that night it escapes. Then, in Part Two, the beast tells the story of being kidnapped by the girl, who force-fed it squirrel food, scared it with a group of beasts and wrapped it in wool. Can the two beasts resolve their differences? A Tale of Two Beasts is an eye-opening story that makes you look at things from a different perspective.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/cutROw_NJvE

post_text:
Tonight‚Äôs story is, "Rent Party Jazz".

(Written by William Miller, illustrated by Charlotte Riley-Webb, and read by Viola Davis)

This story is set in New Orleans in the 1930s. Sonny and his mother are scraping by to pay their rent. Mama works in a fish canning factory, and Sonny works for the coal man before school each morning. When Mama loses her job, they no longer have enough money for the rent and fear that the landlord will turn them out. One day Sonny meets Smilin‚Äô Jack, a jazz musician who is playing his trumpet in Jackson Square. Smilin‚Äô Jack offers to play at a party at Sonny‚Äôs house to help raise money for the rent. The neighbors all come to sing and dance and before they leave, drop some coins in a bucket. Sonny learns how people can help one another ‚Äúif they put their minds and hearts to it.‚Äù

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/JvKaVLLXa30

Tonight‚Äôs story is, "Clark the Shark".

(Written by Bruce Hale, illustrated by Guy Francis, and read by Chris Pine)

Clark is a shark with zing, bang, and boom. Clark zooms into school, crashes through the classroom, and is rowdy at recess. Clark loves life ‚Äì but when his enthusiasm is too much for his friends, Clark‚Äôs teacher, Mrs. Inkydink, helps him figure out a way to tone it down. Clark the Shark celebrates boisterous enthusiasm ‚Äì and knowing when it‚Äôs time for indoor voices.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

In honor of World Book Day 2020 tonight's story is 'Zombies Don‚Äôt Eat Veggies! / ¬°Los Zombis No Comen Verduras!
(Written by Megan and Jorge Lacera, illustrated by Jorge Lacera, and read by Jaime Camil)

Mo Romero is a zombie who loves nothing more than growing, cooking, and eating vegetables. Tomatoes? Tantalizing. Peppers? Pure perfection! The problem? Mo‚Äôs parents insist that their ni√±o eat only zombie cuisine, like arm-panadas and finger foods. They tell Mo over and over that zombies don‚Äôt eat veggies. But Mo can‚Äôt imagine a lifetime of just eating zombie food and giving up his veggies. As he questions his own zombie identity, Mo tries his best to convince his parents to give peas a chance.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/cxF5WURk-RY

post_text:
(Sorry for the late post)

Tonight's story is 'Library Lion'
(Written by Michelle Knudsen, Illustrated by Kevin Hawkes, and Read by Mindy Sterling)

The description below is from the Storyline Online website:

Miss Merriweather, the head librarian, is very particular about rules in the library. No running allowed. And you must be quiet. But when a lion comes to the library one day, no one is sure what to do. There aren‚Äôt any rules about lions in the library. And, as it turns out, this lion seems very well suited to library visiting. His big feet are quiet on the library floor. He makes a comfy backrest for the children at story hour. And he never roars in the library, at least not anymore. But when something terrible happens, the lion quickly comes to the rescue in the only way he knows how.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/T18NCobS43c

post_text:
Tonight's story is 'When Pigasso Met Mootisse'
(Written by: Nina Laden, Illustrated by: Nina Laden, and Read by Eric Close)

The description below is from the Storyline Online website:

What begins as a neighborly overture between a painterly pig and an artsy cow escalates into a monumental modern art mess! Before you can say paint-by-numbers, the two artists are calling each other names and building a fence between them. But it turns out that what divides them also reunites them.

text:
Tonight's story is 'When Pigasso Met Mootisse'
(Written by: Nina Laden, Illustrated by: Nina Laden, and Read by Eric Close)

The description below is from the Storyline Online website:

What begins as a neighborly overture between a painterly pig and an artsy cow escalates into a monumental modern art mess! Before you can say paint-by-numbers, the two artists are calling each other names and building a fence between them. But it turns out that what divides them also reunites them.

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares #WorldArtDay

post_text:
Tonight's story is 'Arnie the Donut'
(Written and illustrated by Laurie Keller and Read by Chris O'Dowd)

The description below is from the Storyline Online website:

At first glance, Arnie looks like an average doughnut - round, cakey, iced and sprinkled, with a hole in the middle. He was made by one of the best bakeries in town, and admittedly his sprinkles are candy-colored. Still, a doughnut is just a doughnut, right? WRONG! Not if Arnie has anything to say about it. And, for a doughnut, he sure seems to have an awful lot to say. Can Arnie change the fate of all doughnuts - or at least have a hand in his own future?

Thank you Storyline Online for these wonderful stories for our kids.

#SmithvilleISD #StorylineOnline #SISDCares
https://youtu.be/6E67n1vZZjQ

post_text:
A friendly reminder that this Friday, April 10th is a school holiday. Even though we are working remotely we all need to enjoy this break from schoolwork.

Our Curbside Meal To-Go will only provide 2 meals this Wednesday, April 8th, due to the School Holiday on Friday. Stay updated on menus and pick-up locations on our website at www.smithvilleisd.org or by clicking https://bit.ly/3aPAdnk.

If you are not receiving text messages from Smithville ISD please email amurray@smithvilleisd.org or call 512-237-5609 and leave your name and the phone number that you would like to receive the texts on.

We hope you all are staying well and know that we miss seeing our kiddos.

#SmithvilleISD #staywell

post_text:
Support Your Local School District! Complete Your 2020 Census!

In 2019, Census Data Determined Funding for:

Title I: Intervention and Support for Students who
Struggle Academically: $350,000
Title II: Extra Teacher for Smaller Class Sizes: $50,000
Title III: English Language Learner Support: $20,000
Title IV: Enrichment Programs (like Robotics and Mentorship): $25,000
Perkins: Career and Technical Education Support: $25,000
TOTAL: $470,000
Per Student = $261

#SmithvilleISD #Census2020 #EveryoneCounts #SupportLocal

post_text:
Did you know that using your body weight with a circuit-type program can be an effective way to maintain strength and aerobic health in a short period of time?

Consider activities that use a variety of movements such as burpees, squats, lunges, and pushups. You may also consider running some sprints down the driveway or take a run around the block in between each activity.

Stay focused and stay healthy - we'll see you all back at Iron Tiger Gym when this is over!

We love you guys! ‚ù§Ô∏è

#IronTigerGym #BetheBESTversionofYou #StayHealthy #StayStrong
text:
Did you know that using your body weight with a circuit-type program can be an effective way to maintain strength and aerobic health in a short period of time?

Consider activities that use a variety of movements such as burpees, squats, lunges, and pushups. You may also consider running some sprints down the driveway or take a run around the block in between each activity.

Stay focused and stay healthy - we'll see you all back at Iron Tiger Gym when this is over!

We love you guys! ‚ù§Ô∏è

#IronTigerGym #BetheBESTversionofYou #StayHealthy #StayStrong

Symptoms of CORONAVIRUS or something else?

Cold or Allergies: itchy Eyes, Stuffy Nose, Sneezing

Flu: Sneezing, Fever, Fatigue, Body Aches, Shortness of Breath, Coughs

Coronavirus: Sneezing, Fever, Fatigue, Body Aches, Shortness of Breath, Coughs,History of Travel, Exposure, Worsening Symptoms

Sources: CDC, Mayo Clinic.
For more information: www.cdc.gov/COVID19-symptoms

PROTECT YOURSELF AT THE GAS PUMPS
‚Ä¢ Wear gloves (kitchen, gardening, ranching, etc) or a plastic bag while pumping gas. Please leave the disposable gloves for our First Responders and Nurses. They must have them to keep us safe.
‚Ä¢ Wipe down gas pump handle and payment keypad with a disinfectant wipe.
‚Ä¢ Sanitize your hands and vehicle door handle.
‚Ä¢ Use your credit card rather than cash.

March 21 at 6:31 PM ¬∑

JOINT STATEMENT OF BASTROP COUNTY LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (Includes Bastrop County, City of Bastrop, City of Elgin, City of Smithville, Bastrop County School Districts, and local Chambers of Commerce)

March 21, 2020

As Bastrop County local government officials, we remind our citizens that it is not appropriate and may be misleading to post or repost unproven information about coronavirus (COVID-19) issues or announcements on social media. Official information will come by and through the Bastrop County Office of Emergency Management as a press release or statement using the OEM social media or other news outlets. You can trust what comes from our Public Information Officers working together in our Joint Information Center. Thank you.

Mayor Connie Schroeder
Mayor Chris Cannon
Mayor Scot Saunders
Judge Paul Pape

NEW HOTLINE HOURS

For Information regarding COVID-19 for Bastrop County citizens:
Bastrop County Local Governments COVID-19 Hotline
Call 512-303-4300.
Open Monday thru Friday 8am ‚Äì 8pm; Saturday 8am ‚Äì 12 pm; and Sunday 9am-1pm.

If you have symptoms or medical questions:
Ascension COVID-19 Medical Hotline
Call 1-833-978-0649.
If you have symptoms that place you in the medium to high risk category they will try to return your call within the hour. If you are a low risk caller they will return your call within 24 hours.

Texas Independence Day is the celebration of the adoption of the Texas Declaration of Independence on March 2, 1836. With this document signed by 59 delegates officially declared independence from Mexico and created the Republic of Texas.

Happy Texas Independence Day, ya'll!
text:
Texas Independence Day is the celebration of the adoption of the Texas Declaration of Independence on March 2, 1836. With this document signed by 59 delegates officially declared independence from Mexico and created the Republic of Texas.

Happy Texas Independence Day, ya'll!

post_text:
Earlier this week Brown Primary School Principal Stephanie Foster joined ESC Region 13's Accountability Roundtable Discussion on Evidence Based Practices and Strategies.

Ms. Foster was joined by peers from districts across the Region 13 Service Area who were featured in a video series. Each of the panelists led round table discussions and took questions from the audience after they watched the videos. Ms. Foster was one of 5 professional educators invited to host the round table discussions. These 5 educators were chosen because of their outstanding leadership and and the work they have exhibited on their campuses and in their districts.

One of the highlights was having an opportunity to watch one of the videos that was created during the 2018-2019 school year featuring how Brown Primary teachers track student learning.

#SmithvilleISD #SISDLeaders #TigerPride #BrownPrimarySchool

post_text:
Thanks to customer donations through the Shoes that Fit Program sponsored by Rack Room Shoes, Smithville ISD students were outfitted with new shoes by the SISD School Nurses Department.

This is the 4th year SISD students have benefitted from the generosity of this program. The school nursing department works closely with teachers to identify students who might benefit from the donations. Any remaining donations are kept at the campus level to outfit students in need on an as needed basis.

If your child might benefit please contact your child‚Äôs school and ask to speak with the nurse or nurse‚Äôs aid.

#SmithvilleISD #RackRoomShoes #ShoesthatFitProgram

post_text:
Smithville High School art classes contribute to The Memory Project which is dedicated to promoting intercultural awareness, friendship, and kindness between children around the world through the universal language of art.

The project facilitates the creation and delivery of heartfelt artwork and poetry made by children for children striving to break cultural barriers, leave children with a unique childhood memory, inspire creativity, show children living in difficult situations that they are valued, and cultivate a kinder world.

We love that our students have been involved with this project for 4 years and we're pretty impressed with their artistic talent.

#SmithvilleISD #SHSTigers #TheMemoryProject #TigerPride

Congratulations to Smithville High School teacher Jennifer Edwards on receiving the Smithville ISD TIGER Award for the 2nd Nine Weeks!

Mrs. Edwards's nomination read:

A great teacher with wonderful classroom management that cares about her students and teaching.

Mrs. Edwards is a teacher who is dedicated to teaching students valuable lessons that are curriculum-based and non-curriculum based.

I have never NOT seen Mrs. Edwards NOT smiling. She always has a cheerful disposition and it reflects in her students‚Äô performance

#SmithvilleISD #TIGERAward #Congratulations

post_text:
Congratulations to Smithville Junior High nurse assistant Kim Hendrix on receiving the Smithville ISD TIGER Award for the 2nd Nine Weeks!

Ms. Hendrix's nomination read:

Kim is a very compassionate school nurse assistant. She takes her time with each student and listens to what they have to say.

I have seen her accept the challenges that come along with her job with grace and courage.

Her eagerness to learn, acceptance to change, and willingness to push through each situation does not go unnoticed.

I am proud to call her a team member of the SISD health team and a valued employee.

#SmithvilleISD #TIGERAward #Congratulations

post_text:
Congratulations to Smithville ISD bus driver Jayne Narro on receiving the Smithville ISD TIGER Award for the 2nd Nine Weeks!

Ms. Narro's nomination read:

Jayne comes in extra early and starts all the buses and vans for drivers on cold mornings to allow for the vehicles to warm up and be ready to roll when the drivers get to work. This is very appreciated. It is so nice to have a warm bus with defrosted windows and mirrors on a cold morning.

Jayne is first to volunteer to help with trips, late runs for absent drivers, mid-day routes, and anything that needs to be done at the bus lot. She cleans the bus shed and straightens the driver boxes.

She communicates with Transportation staff about vehicles that are in need of repair for whatever reason, assists when needed by looking for lost items, and so much more.

#SmithvilleISD #TIGERAward #Congratulations

Jayne is first to volunteer to help with trips, late runs for absent drivers, mid-day routes, and anything that needs to be done at the bus lot. She cleans the bus shed and straightens the driver boxes.

She communicates with Transportation staff about vehicles that are in need of repair for whatever reason, assists when needed by looking for lost items, and so much more.

#SmithvilleISD #TIGERAward #Congratulations

post_text:
Congratulations to Smithville Elementary counselor Cory Williams on receiving the Smithville ISD TIGER Award for the 2nd Nine Weeks!

Mrs. Williams's nomination read:

Cory embraces every child that she comes in contact with; not just the usual physical hugs, but engaging with them conversationally and showing them caring and love, getting involved in their everyday lives and what is going on with them both at home, as well as at school. And, it is not just the littles that she shows this deep interest in; but peers alike feel the effort and earnestness she puts forth in showing genuine concern for we adults, as well.

She has initiated a new program on our campus to allow teachers to build up others with sweet compliments from week to week--allowing them to feel that their "going the extra mile" really did get noticed!!!

#SmithvilleISD #TIGERAward #Congratulations

And, it is not just the littles that she shows this deep interest in; but peers alike feel the effort and earnestness she puts forth in showing genuine concern for we adults, as well.

#SmithvilleISD #TIGERAward #Congratulations

post_text:
Congratulations to Brown Primary School teacher Rachel Hurst on receiving the Smithville ISD TIGER Award for the 2nd Nine Weeks!

Ms. Hurst's nomination read:

Rachel always jumps in to volunteer at Brown Primary. On top of being a great classroom teacher, she serves on the District Site-Based Committee and is Vice President of the Brown Primary Booster Club.

Rachel has a heart for kids. She works hard each day to meet their needs. She is always looking for ways to improve her skills so that she can better serve the littles of BP.

Rachel is a valuable member of the Brown Primary staff and truly deserves to be recognized for her hard work and contributions.

#SmithvilleISD #TIGERAward #Congratulations

post_text:
Connecting 54 years of #TigerPride today at Smithville High School.

Players from the 1965 team who made it to the Regional Quarterfinal game Dan Young, Phil Tovar, and Howard Burns, Jr. came to SHS for a photo shoot with their great nephew and grandsons, Nick Young, Jagger Tiner, and Lane Otto.

Left to right: Nick Young and Great Uncle Dan Young, Grandfather Phil Tovar and Jagger Tiner, and Grandfather Howard Burns, Jr. with Lane Otto.

Listening to the Tigers from the 1965 team sharing vivid stories of that final playoff game made it feel like it happened just yesterday. Such a great feeling to have this moment with the past and present coming together.

#SmithvilleISD #SHSTigerFootball #TigerPride #GoTigers

Smithville ISD has been notified that the 4th Avenue Bridge has been closed by the Texas Department of Transportation.

SISD buses are unable to use the ‚ÄòBo Peep‚Äô Crossing on Live Oak due to the height of the crossing. School vans will be used to transport students living on 'the hill' via the crossing on Live Oak.

For estimations on pick-up and drop-off times please follow this link: http://bit.ly/37mk8Eo (www.SmithvilleISD.org)

Parents have been notified via phone, email, and text message. Students have been given a letter to give to their parents.

shared_text:
Smithville Tiger Band
November 12, 2019 at 7:42 AM ¬∑

We are proud to announce that the SJHS Tiger Band had 20 Tiger Band Members earn All Region Band honors this past Saturday with one selected as an alternate. These SJHS Band Members will attend the Region 18 & 26 Clinic this Friday and Saturday and perform a free public concert on Saturday, Nov. 16th at 5 p.m. in the Bastrop ISD Performing Arts Center! The concert will also feature a performance by the All Region Jazz Band. Congratulations to these Smithville Junior High Band members!

Amy Frushay - Flute
Katelyn Curry-Russel - Flute
Laney Summarell - Flute
Devany Flores - Flute
Lacy Copeland - Flute
Carina Berryann - Bb Clarinet
Joanna Ngim - Bb Clarinet
Arabella Gutierrez - Bb Clarinet
Trinity Campion - Bb Clarinet
Annabella Bryan - Bass Clarinet
Bishop Allison - Baritone Saxophone
Cody Kennon - Trumpet
Nathan Ervin - Trumpet
Daisy Leza - Trumpet
Brianna Knight - Trumpet
Emma Burch - Trumpet
Grace Hamilton - French Horn
Pedro Duran Jr. - French Horn
Antonio Blasco - Trombone
Claire Layfield - Trombone

Thanks to Doug Berryann, of Doug's Plumbing Co., Smithville High School students, maintenance staff, and city workers were able to attend a special demonstration presented by the Texas State Plumbing Board.

The presentation included education and training on water heaters and back-flow issues. We were all impressed with the educational opportunity and the reinforcement on the importance of hiring professional plumbers.

post_text:
(Friday, November 1, 2019) This morning a Smithville ISD bus was involved in a minor accident. The school bus was at a stop and was rear-ended by a vehicle.

The Smithville Police Department was contacted and arrived on the scene quickly. Smithville ISD sent a school nurse to the accident scene to assess the students and bus driver and there were no injuries. Everyone on the bus is ok. Parents are being notified by campus personnel.

_________________________________________________

A Smithville ISD bus #12 (Bear) was involved in a minor accident on Marburger St. this morning.

The Smithville Police Department is at the scene of the accident. A school nurse has checked out all of the children on the bus and has reported that everyone is ok. Parents will be notified.

The route is delayed.

An update will be shared when more information is available.

post_text:
At approximately 7:00 am this morning a Smithville ISD bus (Dragon) was involved in a minor incident. An individual ran across the road in front of the moving bus. The bus driver applied their brakes to avoid hitting the individual, resulting in the bus making contact with a parked vehicle.

The Smithville Police Department was contacted and arrived on the scene quickly. After assessing the situation Smithville PD advised the bus driver to continue the route. School nurses are checking on the students and parents are being notified.

post_text:
Congratulations once again Smithville Tiger Band!!

#SHSTigerBand #TigerPride #SmithvilleISD
shared_text:
Smithville Tiger Band
October 13, 2019 at 9:28 AM ¬∑

Congratulations to the Tiger Band for their outstanding performances yesterday at the Edna Marching Invitational. The band earned 1st division ratings from all judges, 1st place Colorguard, and 3rd place in Class 4A in prelims. At the finals contest, the Tiger Band had an even better performance and passed all of 1st and 2nd placed 4A groups from prelims and placed 3rd place behind the two 6A groups (Davis 1st / Harker Heights 2nd). We were 3rd out of the 28 bands that started the day from preliminaries. Next Saturday, the Tiger Band travels to Giddings for the the UIL Regional Marching Band Contest. We perform at 6:45 p.m. Come out and support your Tiger Band!

SISD After School Program added 8 new photos to the album: ACE - Back to School Cooking Camp and Zoo Trip ‚Äî with The Smithville Community Gardens and Smithville Public Library at San Antonio Zoo.
October 10, 2019 at 4:51 PM ¬∑ San Antonio, TX ¬∑

In conjunction with the Smithville Public Library, Smithville Community Gardens, and We Grow, We Cook, We Eat, the ACE program sponsored a back to school camp where students spent four days learning about growing their own food and making dishes with food from the Smithville Community Garden. On the final day, those with perfect attendance visited the San Antonio Zoo.

post_text:
SISD is looking for members of the community to serve as mentors for our students.

Come learn how 30 minutes a week can make a positive difference in the life of a child.

Let us know if you plan to attend by completing the form online at http://bit.ly/2nRnoWa or just show up on Tuesday, October 8, 2019, from 9:00 am - 10:30 am in the Media Lab on the 2nd Floor of the Central Administration Building located at 901 N.E. 6th Street, Smithville, Texas 78957. (There is no cost to become a mentor.)

For more information please contact Ana L. Murray, District Communications Officer at 512-237-2487 ext. 7275 or amurray@smithvilleisd.org.

The Smithville ISD Mentor Program offers the opportunity to members of the community to serve as a mentor, benefiting the students, the school district and the community.

A positive mentor/mentee relationship can make a huge difference in the life of a young person.

#SmithvilleISD #BeaMentor #mentoring

Can't wait to open the doors of our new junior high campus for the community to see!

If you can't make the ribbon cutting and open house we'll be open on Thursday, August 22nd from 6:00-7:00 p.m. for another open house/meet the teacher. (Student schedules will be handed out on the first day of school - August 26th)

See you there!

post_text:
Smithville ISD staff were greeted with a pancake breakfast cooked up by campus and district administrators at the SISD General Convocation. Thank you First National Bank for sponsoring our breakfast and bringing some goodies for everyone.

School Board President Grant Gutierrez welcomed the staff on behalf of the Board of Trustees and thanked them for their work and service to come during the new year.

Superintendent Cheryl Burns shared her message, with help from veteran staff, about taking care of kids and building relationships, leaving everyone pumped and ready to go for 2019-2020!

#SmithvilleISD #WelcomeBack #TigerPride #FortheKids

Smithville ISD staff were greeted with a pancake breakfast cooked up by campus and district administrators at the SISD General Convocation. Thank you First National Bank for sponsoring our breakfast and bringing some goodies for everyone.

School Board President Grant Gutierrez welcomed the staff on behalf of the Board of Trustees and thanked them for their work and service to come during the new year.

Superintendent Cheryl Burns shared her message, with help from veteran staff, about taking care of kids and building relationships, leaving everyone pumped and ready to go for 2019-2020!

post_text:
Smithville ISD and the community welcomed our new staff this week. Staff began their orientation with breakfast sponsored by the Smithville Area Chamber of Commerce Committee We Support Smithville ISD followed by a tour of Smithville with stops at the Smithville Heritage Society, Smithville, Texas City Hall, First National Bank, Scott Saunders Farmers Insurance Agent, Golden Girls Boutique, Olde World Bakery, E.H. Mercantile, and Subway for lunch sponsored by Subway and E.H. Mercantile.

New staff ended their day at the Smithville Pard Recreation Center where they learned about the services available to them through the City of Smithville‚Äôs Recreation Center.

The staff was also treated to goodie bags from many Smithville Area Chamber of Commerce business members. A special thank you to Scott Alan Saunders Jr, Gwendolyn LaMance Watkins, The Front Room Wine Bar, and The Winning Shot Sports Photography for the after-hours treat.

Thank you also to our wonderful tour guide April Daniels and our train driver Scott Saunders, Sr.

#SmithvilleISD #WelcomeNewStaff #NewStaffLuncheon

Mercantile, and Subway for lunch sponsored by Subway and E.H. Mercantile.

New staff ended their day at the Smithville Pard Recreation Center where they learned about the services available to them through the City of Smithville‚Äôs Recreation Center.

Thank you also to our wonderful tour guide April Daniels and our train driver Scott Saunders, Sr.
